content:
Such a process rarely fixes anything. Some system integration issue can be fixed by a reinstall. Any "clean" install will require replacing the profile and that is where your mail is stored.

So can we just get to the problem, instead of wasting time on reinstalls that don't do anything useful, but often make recovering from whatever to initial problem was much much harder.

content:
For us to better investigate this issue, we will need some more information.

Could you please do the following?

  1. Open the menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information, then click Copy text to Clipboard.
  2. Go to https://pastebin.mozilla.org/, paste the clipboard by right clicking in the large text area, select paste from the menu, change the retention period to expire in 28 days, use the Paste Snippet button to create a page containing your info, then copy the resulting URL (address) of the page created.
  3. Open a reply to this post, and paste the URL to your troubleshooting information you just copied.
  4. Please also provide results for the following test on your system
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Merhaba,

MEB'deki sistemin nasıl işlediğini maalesef bilmiyorum ama yaşadığınız sorunla ilgili bir fikrim oluştu.

MEB'in kullandığı filtrede mail.google.com web sitesini erişim izin verildiği için web tarayıcınız üzerinden Gmail'e ulaşabiliyorsunuz. Fakat Gmail'in kullandığı IMAP ve SMTP sunucularına erişim engellenmiş. Bu durumda web tarayıcısı dışında hiçbir uygulama üzerinden e-postalarınıza erişemezsiniz. Gmail sunucuları de değil doğrudan aşağıda belirtiğim portlar da engellenmiş olabilir. Bu durumda Gmail dışında e-posta sağlayıcılarına da erişilemeyecektir.

Gmail'e erişebilmeniz için aşağıdaki sunucu ve portlara erişim izni verilmesi gerekiyor: imap.gmail.com:993 smtp.gmail.com:465 smtp.gmail.com:587

Fakat paylaştığınız ekran görüntüsünden sadece web siteleri için erişim talebinde bulunabileceğinizi anlıyorum. Paylaştığım sunucu adresleri web sitesi değil. Dolayısıyla o sistem dahilinde erişim izni verilmesi mümkün olmayabilir. Yine de şansınızı deneyebilirsiniz.

content:
Well I see you have a load of opinions aboput what Thunderbird should do, buyt have not turned off the junk controls in Thunderbird in settings. Once you do that Thunderbird will do nothing with junk. It will not even look at it. So perhaps make the setting change. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages

Now if you issue continues after junk processing it turned off in Thunderbird (and I expect they will) it is not Thunderbird that has done the placements or the decision making.

The fact that there are no real definitions or agreed method for dealing with SPAM makes it complicated. Most third parts antivirus programs have some sort of antivirus scam/spam tool that does an appalling job of managing spam. Sometimes mail is just deleted it outright, sometimes it puts mail in a spam or junk folder. Trend had a particularly egregious tool at one point. But i have over a decade of reading about the many failings of Antivirus products. Usually the issue is blamed on Thunderbird by folk that do not realize they have this antivirus tool making a mess of things.

These days most folk also configure their mail accounts as IMAP so they get all their server side folders, and every provider I have seen has some sort of spam filtering of their own. Usually this is something you can not opt out of and they are particularly good at filing family mail as SPAM. The Yahoo bulk mail one will even keep putting the same email back in SPAM even after you move it somewhere else and say the mail is not spam.

Ok, if you reached the menu that lists accounts and the checkboxes for folders and yours isn't there, then do this: - untick unified folders - exit thunderbird - in profile Mail folder, delete 'smart mailboxes' - in profile, delete virtualfolders.dat - restart thunderbird and set unified folders

If you don't know how to locate the profile then do this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' in left side and click 'open folder' - exit thunderbird. you are now in the profile

content: Ok, now it makes sense. Yes, I had mentioned that earlier, but possibly overlooked. Since 'inbox' appears under Unified Folders, my focus had been there. Thunderbird shows ALL folders. If the folder is one where the same name is used that is used by other accounts, then it appears within the unified folders. If the folder is unique to the account, then it appears separately below. So, no problem. All is well. Please mark this solved. Whew!  :) Thanks for participating, Rick.

content:
Thunderbird è un software gratuito offerto senza garanzie (è scritto anche nella licenza d'uso che l'utente accetta durante l'installazione). Ne segue che non esiste un supporto tecnico (chi paga?) ne tanto meno un numero di telefono per l'assistenza. Esiste questo forum, ma è da intendersi solo come spazio di discussione per gli utenti Mozilla.

Se hai un contratto di assistenza con qualche soggetto terzo, è eventualmente a questi che devi rivolgerti.

Per quanto riguarda il tuo problema, da queste situazioni ci si tutela facendo un backup periodico. Se ne hai fatto uno il ripristino del profilo è piuttosto semplice -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_ripristinare-un-profilo-da-una-sua-copia (anche se ovviamente si perdono i messaggi successi alla data di backup).

Senza un backup bisogna capire esattamente cosa è ancora presente nel profilo. I file msf sono solo degli indici e non contengono la posta. Le email sono contenute in file formato mbox senza alcuna estensione. Di solito ad ogni file msf corrisponde un file senza estensione che contiene i messaggi.

content:
Hi, your problem description is typical for a broken prefs.js file. This mostly happens during TB or PC crashes or a current interruption. TB renames the damaged prefs.js file in the profile to prefs-1.js (or invalidprefs.js) and creates a new virgin prefs.js file (5 to 7 kB size) which contains no account data. So on startup doesn't find any account and invites the user to create an account. Go to your profile folder and search for a prefs-1.js file (or invalidprefs.js) to confirm my diagnosis.

The easiest way to solve this problem is to copy the prefs.js file from a recent profile backup and paste it in the profile folder. TB must be shut down during this manoeuvre.
creator: Mapenzi

content: Hello Mapenzi, Thanks for your quick reply. I found these files but I don't have a backup.
creator: adam_oued

content:
No backup, no pity .... If you have IMAP accounts you just re-create your accounts which will be automatically synchronized with the server.

If you have POP accounts the punishment is more severe: After re-creating a POP account you'll have to "link" it with the corresponding "pop.xxx.xx" account folder (where the account's messages are still stored) in the "Mail" folder of the Thunderbird profile following this description: go to Account Settings > select the re-created POP account > click Server Settings > Message Store > Local Directory > click button "Browse...." Then navigate to the corresponding "pop.xxx.xx" account folder in "Mail' in the profile folder, select the account folder and click on "Open". This done Thunderbird will invite you to a restart of the application and you should see the folders and messages of this POP account.

https://postimg.cc/FYFDwX7V
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Andrew said
Arlev, As for the copying, yes, I just copied the Profile folder as per the instructions I linked in my original post.

As the cited SUMO article postulates you should have copied the entire Thunderbird folder - not only the profile folder - from the old computer and paste it - TB shut down - on the new PC in .... \AppData\Roaming\ ..here in place of the Thunderbird folder which has been created on the first TB run. If you transplant only the TB profile folder on the new PC, TB will not recognize this profile because the important file profiles.ini contains the path to and the name of the profile which has been created on first run and which you just replaced with the profile from the old PC.

content:
I'm assuming same version number has been installed on each computer.

Check the Firewall on computer B (W11) - has the Thunderbird program set up as allowed. Note: Firewall may be the default that comes with computer or may be controlled by an Anti-Virus product you installed.

On computer A (W10)

  • Exit Thunderbird
  • Access Profile via the following method:
  • In windows search type: %Appdata% - see image as guide
  • Select %Appdata% file folder
  • Click on 'Roaming'
  • Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder to an external drive

On computer B (W11)

  • Exit Thunderbird
  • Access Profile via the following method:
  • In windows search type: %Appdata% - see image as guide
  • Select %Appdata% file folder
  • Click on 'Roaming'
  • Delete the 'Thunderbird' folder - it got created by default.
  • On external drive - Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder which came from the W10 computer.
  • Paste the copied 'Thunderbird' folder into the 'Roaming' Folder.

start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Andrew said
Mapenzi, Thanks for your reply. The SUMO article is a bit confusing because in the first part (source) it refers to copying the Thunderbird folder. But in the second part (destination) it refers to having copied the Thunderbird profile folder.

You are right, parts of this article are confusing and several user in Mozilla forums have been misled, in particular by the line "From your Thunderbird profile folder in Finder, open the Go menu and select Enclosing Folder two times." It means: from the profile folder navigate two levels higher and you will have selected the "Thunderbird" folder (which you should copy from the old PC to the new PC and paste in ...\AppData\Roaming\)

Any idea what this means?

creator: Bartholo

content:
Andrew said
Any idea what this means?
  • .mozmsgs folders and *.wdseml files are generated by the Windows search. Normally you shouldn't see them in the Thunderbird profile folder.

In my experience they are stored in the profile when certain message storages are externalized from the profile folder. You can delete them without danger since they contain no messages; just some infos like .msf files.

creator: arlev

content:
That sounds a bit confusing. I'm thinking maybe you mean 12 = Dec and 17 = date eg: 17th Dec year unknown So, 19th Dec is only 2 days later. I'm wondering if you are really talking about 'profiles'.

One profile contains everything - your address books, your calendars, all your various mail accounts for different email addresses, all your preferences - the lot. Most people will only have one profile name folder although several may have two. A profile name folder usually takes this sort of naming using letters and numbers: 'abc1234x.default' or 'abc1234x.default release'

Perhaps it would be a good idea to post an image showing what you are talking about.

On Windows 11 if everything is stored in default location you will find your Profiles in this location:

  • In windows search type : %Appdata% - see image as guide
  • Select %Appdata% file folder
  • Click on 'Roaming'
  • The 'Thunderbird' folder contains everything - you would get a copy of that if intending to perform a backup.
  • Click on 'Thunderbird to see contents
  • clickon the 'Profiles' folder to see list of Profiles
  • The Profiles folder will show a list of all your 'profile' name folders.

You can also see what Profiles are installed via Thunderbird program In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - near the bottom locate 'Profiles' and click on 'about:profiles'
  • It opens in a new tab and it will show a list of your 'profiles' and also tell you which profile is the current default being used.

Please note: If you have Firefox then it will also use profiles. Windows will also create some 'profile' folders in the 'Local' folder which it uses to help cache data.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: arlev

content:
At this point, it's abit unknown so check out a few things. As you are not getting any error other than no new mail - this could be various reasons - blocked from internet, webmail not receiving mail due to maxed out on quota, server settings not up to date.

1. Check Firewall. Exit Thunderbird Access Firewall - this might be the default which came with computer or controlled by an Anti-Virus program you installed. Thunderbird must be set as an allowed program.

Then you can be sure the Firewall is not causing an issue.

2. Check Password Logon to webmail account via a browser - if you get access you know password is good.

3. Log on to webmail and see if there are new emails on server - if the webmail account does not have new mail then Thunderbird is not going to display any new mail. Check you server quota - if you have used up all your server quota then the server is incapable of receiving new mail. You will need to delete a load of emails off the server to create somne space. Please note if you do this and you use an IMAP account - those emails will also get deleted from the imap account. So before you delete anything - in Thunderbird, get 'Copies' of important emails put into the 'Local Folders' account.

4. Check current Account Settings AS I have no idea what typ of account you are using I've posted all info, so it's important if you have Account set up to use Pop then it must use pop server settings and same goes for imap - do not attempt to swap settings. If you have Pop and want Imap then you will need to create a new mail account for the imap option.

POP

  • Incoming Server: pop.shaw.ca
  • Port: 995
  • Security Type: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • username = full email address (normally full but website does mention first part only)
  • password - same one as used to access webmail account

IMAP

  • Incoming Mail Server: imap.shaw.ca
  • Incoming Port: 993
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • Username: Shaw email address without the @shaw.ca
  • Password: same one as used to access webmail account

SMTP

  • Outgoing Mail Server: mail.shaw.ca
  • Port: 587
  • Connection SEcurity : STARTTLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • username = full email address
  • password - same one as used to access webmail.

content:
Attachments in an email are a continuous mime encoded block of text. To put it bluntly the attachment ceases to exist as a discrete file at the time it is attached. For this reason you can not edit them.

When you view or save or open an attachment, Thunderbird decodes the MIME text, builds a file and writes it to the system temp folder. Then it starts trying to do what you have asked. SO I suggest if you need to edit the file on your drafts that you detach it as an attachment (the attachment is discarded) and attach the edited file.

creator: info5531

content:
Compacting is honestly a bit of a mess at the moment. I have seen a number of bugs raised.

Generally I would suggest just setting the auto-compact figure in settings to a few megabytes and never doing it manually at all, or just skipping it entirely for the time being.

Essentially the trash should not be compacted it should be emptied as it is not meant to be a long term storage location at all. Perhaps set it to auto empty of shutdown in account settings.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Hi Matt, I did it and automatic compacting really worked without problems. Thank you very much for your support and have a great Christmas! Michal

content: You need to go into account settings. Locate the menu entry of outgoing servers (SMTP) fine the one that you are using in the list and change the authentication to normal password. It is very unusual for any provider to allow you to send mail unauthenticated. That would mean they had an open relay and would be blacklisted for spam in minutes.
